etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Stephen Weston (1747–1830), antiquary and classical scholar. From classical Latin alūmin-, alūmen alum + -ite, after French aluminite

definitions: A whitish mineral typically occurring in opaque, clay-like masses and consisting of a hydrated basic sulphate of aluminium.

notes.text: Chemical formula: Al₂SO₄(OH)₄·7H₂O. Crystal system: monoclinic.
